docs.lead_paragraph: It has taken hundreds of hours of therapy, but Jason Poole, a 23-year old Marine corporal, has learned all over again to speak and to walk. At times, though, words still elude him. He can read barely 16 words a minute. His memory can be fickle, his thinking delayed. Injured by a roadside bomb in Iraq, he is blind in his left eye, deaf in his left ear, weak on his right side and still getting used to his new face, which was rebuilt with skin and bone grafts and 75 to 100 titanium screws and plates. Even so, those who know Corporal Poole say his personality -- gregarious, kind and funny -- has remained intact. Wounded on patrol near the Syrian border on June 30, 2004, he considers himself lucky to be alive. So do his doctors. ''Basically I want to get my life back,'' he said. ''I'm really trying.''

headline.main: THE WOUNDED: THE SURVIVORS -- Surviving Multiple Injuries; Struggling Back From War's Once-Deadly Wounds

docs.abstract: Profile of Cpl Jason Poole, who was wounded in Iraq by roadside bomb near Syrian border on June 30, 2004, and is working to regain his life; men and women who have suffered devastating injuries that would have been fatal in earlier wars have been saved in Iraq by helmets, body armor, advances in battlefield medicine and swift evacuation to hospitals, but survivors are coming home with grave injuries that will transform their lives; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Men and women living with injuries that would have been fatal in earlier wars are a singular legacy of the war in Iraq.

multimedia.credit: Men and women living with injuries that would have been fatal in earlier wars are a singular legacy of the war in Iraq.

docs.lead_paragraph: ASK who is served by Suffolk County's public health nurses, and you'll hear about people like Junie McCleod of Bay Shore, who calls herself ''a regular mom with a lot of love.'' She has eight children in her household, six of them disabled; one, a 2-year-old, has cerebral palsy. Or Doreen Cobb of Mastic, a double amputee struggling to maintain her independence at age 58, despite persistent health problems like high blood pressure and depression.

headline.main: On the East End, A Nursing Shortage Is Felt Most Deeply

docs.snippet: Advocates for Suffolk County's public health nurses say the nurses are understaffed and overwhelmed.

docs.snippet: In the future, whether you have $15 million socked away or $1,500, nothing will matter except health care benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: MANY employers who cut their staff during the recession later turned to contract workers to handle new business or do short-term technology tasks. For unemployed workers, a contract was often one of the few job opportunities available, particularly in technology-related fields. Given the nature of contracting, employers did not provide health insurance or other benefits and some contractors didn't know which day would be their last.
docs.snippet: More workers are choosing a self-directed career, leaving behind company politics and gaining flexibility.

docs.lead_paragraph: Typically, when a union's members reject a contract, negotiators from management and labor reconvene and seek to reach a revised deal -- often with a few tweaks -- that is more palatable to the union's rank and file yet does not cost management an extra cent. But New York City's continuing transit dispute, which involved the first systemwide strike in a quarter-century, has not followed tried-and-true patterns.

headline.main: In Transit Dispute, Navigating Without a Map

docs.abstract: Recent strike marks first time New York City transit workers have gone on strike first and then voted down contract; stunned union leaders and Metropolitan Transit Authority are unsure how to put contract back together again; dissent and political jockeying within Local 100 of Transport Workers Union means militant members could be prone to wildcat job action or slowdown; workers are angry at union president Roger Toussaint, at MTA for demanding concessions when it had $1 billion surplus and at Gov Pataki for threatening to block refunds on pension contributions
docs.snippet: New York City's continuing transit dispute, which involved the first systemwide strike in a quarter-century, has not followed tried-and-true patterns.

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and SEWELL CHAN

docs.lead_paragraph: IT had all the markings of a typical emergency department waiting room: magazines scattered on end tables; a wall-mounted television; more than two dozen institutional chairs lining the walls. Only the people were missing. On a recent weekday afternoon, the waiting room at the Hudson Valley Hospital Center here was empty. The hospital has adopted a no-wait emergency room procedure. A recent $1 million renovation eliminated the registration desk. A greeter now sends patients to one of three triage rooms. Insurance information is taken at bedside. The department is split into two zones: fast track, for minor injuries and illnesses treatable by nurse practitioners, and critical care.

headline.main: New at E.R.'s: More Sense Of Urgency

docs.snippet: Hospitals around the country are trying to reduce waiting times, expand working space, improve privacy and upgrade technology.

docs.lead_paragraph: BEFORE Web logs, Robert Moses described old-fashioned letter writing as good exercise. ''I have no doubt,'' wrote Moses, who had few doubts about anything, ''that correspondence on a wide variety of topics with a circle of devoted friends has done much to keep Charles C. Burlingham, the distinguished lawyer and inveterate reformer, alive and alert.'' Robert A. Caro immortalized Moses as the consummate New York power broker. Mr. Burlingham, on the other hand, ''had no power, no elective office or constituency at the polls,'' George Martin writes in his new biography, ''CCB: The Life and Century of Charles C. Burlingham'' (Hill and Wang, $35), ''but he had influence with many who did, presidents and chief justice of the United States, governors of the state, and mayors of the city, most notably Franklin D. Roosevelt and Fiorello La Guardia.''
docs.snippet: Reviews of books that shed light on how New York City works.

The present system does not treat the majority of employees and investors fairly, and a democratic government should do something about it. We need federal laws that:

headline.main: Putting the Brakes on Executive Pay

docs.lead_paragraph: SPADICIA HARRIS was beaming. She was spending her last day at the Maria Fareri Children's Hospital at the Westchester Medical Center, where she had been hospitalized for cancer treatment since November. Spadicia, an 8-year-old from Antigua, talked about one feature of the hospital that she may miss -- the original artwork. ''I love it,'' she said, as she stood near a large black-and-white crayon drawing of a ballet dancer by the contemporary American artist Karen Kilimnik.

headline.main: Hospital Art Designs That Keep Healing in Mind

docs.lead_paragraph: In the late 1990's, Katy Sparks won accolades as executive chef at Quilty's, a chic restaurant in SoHo. She was named one of Food & Wine's ''best new chefs'' in 1998 and a ''rising star chef'' by both Wine Spectator and Restaurant Hospitality magazines. Then, in 2001, the bottom fell out of New York's restaurant business, and all that praise was not enough to keep Quilty's afloat. Ms. Sparks, who was a new mother, the main earner in her household and a homeowner, was out of a job for the first time in her career.

headline.main: Wanted: Chic Chefs for Grocery Stores

docs.snippet: A restaurant chefnow cooking for agourmet market ishome by dinner.
